etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in Richard Bancroft (bap. 1544, d. 1610), archbishop of Canterbury. From admonition + -er

definitions: A person who admonishes; an admonisher; specifically (chiefly with capital initial) any of the Puritans associated with the Admonition to the Parliament of 1572, condemning the episcopal government and ceremonies of the Church of England.

notes.text: The authors of the Admonition were the Oxford graduates John Field and Thomas Wilcox, who were supported by Thomas Cartwright, a former Chair of Divinity at Cambridge.
